Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of a Sophomore-Level Course "Introduction of Renewable Energy Manufacturing" and Faculty Expertise

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is to develop, assess, revise, and disseminate a sophomore-level course, ?Introduction of Renewable Energy Manufacturing,? and to develop faculty expertise in teaching the course. Project tasks include: (1) draft the textbook for the course and publish it though a self-publishing company; (2) develop lab modules; (3) draft the lab manual and publish it though a self-publishing company; (4) establish a website that contains links to relevant YouTube videos and homework assignments; (5) develop assessment questions for students; (6) visit related manufacturing companies and national renewable energy labs; (7) teach the course at three institutions and conduct both informative and summative assessments; (8) analyze assessment results; (9) revise the draft textbook and lab manual based on assessment results; (10) submit revised textbook and lab manual to a regular publisher; and (11) publish journal and conference papers and make presentations to disseminate findings.

The proposed work will have significant impacts on training the nation?s future workforce in renewable energy manufacturing. Such a workforce is critical for the U.S. to secure its global leadership in the renewable energy industry. This will greatly benefit the U.S. economy, energy security, environment, and society in general. The collaborative work among the three institutions, one of which is a HBCU, will broaden participation and promote diversity in STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objectives of this project are to develop, assess, revise, and disseminate a sophomore level course, “Introduction of Renewable Energy Manufacturing,” and to cultivate faculty expertise in teaching the course. The project spans three institutions with unique characteristics, an HBCU (historically black colleges and universities) institution – North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University (NC A&T), a non-PhD-granting institution – Oregon Institute of Technology (OIT), and an EPSCoR institution – Kansas State University (KSU).

The project started in January, 2013 and will end in by January, 2017, during which period, we have achieved the following outcomes:

  • Draft the textbook for course and publish it though a self-publishing company: we wrote, revised, improved and published the book "Introduction to Renewable Energy Manufacturing"; the PI and Co-PI of Oregon Institute of Technology contributed two chapters in this book, namely "Ocean Energy" and "High Enthalpy Geothermal Energy".
  • We established a website (a YouTube channel) that contains links to relevant YouTube videos and homework assignments.
  • We have offered a 300-level "Renewable Energy Manufacturing" course on both campuses of our university and did the assessment by following the rubrics and procedure developed by OEIE of Kansas State University; all classes have used the textbook we wrote in the current NSF project. We developed assessment questions for students to answer when they take the course. We also conducted the required assessments.
  • We have published and presented two papers and presented a poster at multiple professional conferences to disseminate the outcomes of the current NSF project.
  • As part of the faculty expertise development, we visited manufacturing companies in renewable energy fields, renewable energy technology demo center and national energy lab. 
  • MET/MFG 307 Renewable Energy Manufacturing has now become a regular course and will be taught on a regular basis from now on. We will revise our textbook further. We will write another grant proposal to build the labs. We will use the lab manual drafted by our partner school, Kansas State University, to offer labs in the course once the lab is built.
